newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk Yasarbank aims 20 pct asset growth in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Turk Yasarbank aims 20 pct asset growth in 1997.

text.p: Turkey's Tutunculer Bankasi Yasarbank, a medium-scale private commercial bank, aims to increase its assets by 20 percent in dollar terms, its general manager Nadir Topcuoglu said.
"We are planning to increase our assets to at least $1.8 billion this year from $1.5 billion (at end-1996)," Topcuoglu told Reuters.
"However, I don't think that there will be a sharp increase in profits. Because we are trying to complete a series of investments in 1997," he said.
He added that developments in the first quarter were in line with the growth plans and there was no need for a revision in the 1997 targets.
Topcuoglu said their aim was a broad client base in loans by addressing a large number of small and medium-scale firms rather than concentrating on a few big corporates.
The bank also sought to increase deposits and foreign trade activities this year, he added.
"We are planning to increase our capital by September," Topcuoglu said, but did not give the amount of the planned capital rise.
The bank, which changed its name from Tutunbank to Yasarbank last year, doubled its capital to 10 trillion lira earlier this year.
Yasarbank, with 78 domestic branches and a banking subsidiary in Berlin, Germany, is mainly owned by Turkey's food, brewery and paint group Yasar Holding.
Topcuoglu said the bank was also planning to secure a $30 million syndicated loan this year, but did not elaborate.
